awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: Reconstructing CO2 fertilization with herbaria
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Research Using Biological Collections. The fellow, Leander Anderegg, is conducting research and receiving training that utilizes biological collections in innovative ways, and is being mentored by two sponsoring scientists at two host institutions: Todd Dawson (University of California-Berkeley) and Joseph Berry (Carnegie Institute for Science). The fellow is investigating how plants have responded to rising amounts of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere over the past century, in order to predict how plants will respond to increasing human CO2 emissions in the future. Plants are like merchants: they essentially trade water to the atmosphere in exchange for the CO2 they need to produce sugars through photosynthesis. By burning fossil fuels, humans have changed the global carbon-water exchange rate in plants' favor by making it less water-expensive to 'buy' CO2 from the atmosphere. Theoretically, this could increase plant growth around the world, improving crop yields and increasing how much of our CO2 emissions ecosystems can absorb from the atmosphere in the future. However, recent observations suggest that this CO2 fertilization effect is far more limited and variable than previously thought. This research explores why CO2 fertilization responses are so complex, focusing on how drought stress and differences between plant species determine if and how a plant responds to rising atmospheric CO2.

The fellow is using hundred-year-old plant samples from museum herbarium collections along with modern samples collected from the same locations to reconstruct how tree species across California have responded to rising CO2. The fellow is comparing the morphology, anatomy and chemical composition of these historical and modern leaves to determine how trees have changed their physiology over the past century. The historical and contemporary records of plant responses to CO2 collected through this research are also revealing how CO2 fertilization varies across species and climates. The fellow is using this information, along with tree growth reconstructions from tree cores and mechanistic photosynthesis models, to understand how water availability and species physiology dictate tree responses to elevated CO2. This work is helping to reconcile the results of short-term CO2 fertilization experiments and long-term observations from tree rings of the exchange rate between water and CO2. A nuanced understanding of the plant traits and environmental conditions that lead to different CO2 fertilization responses will improve our ability to predict terrestrial ecosystem function under accelerating environmental change. The fellow is being trained in plant anatomical, isotopic and modeling techniques while also developing new methods for unlocking critical information from underused herbarium collections.

por.por_cntn:
Trees, which can live hundreds or even thousands of years, must survive enormous fluctuations in their environment. They can’t move, so they must instead tweak their physiology to deal with droughts, heatwaves, cold snaps, and various other weather fluctuations. Human-caused climate change is testing trees’ ability to deal with changing environments by simultaneously increasing average temperatures, changing precipitation patterns, raising atmospheric CO2 (which plants use to make sugars through photosynthesis), and increasing the number and severity of extreme events like droughts. This NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship used spatial variation in tree physiology, or the differences between individuals of the same species growing in drastically different environments, to explore how trees can respond to climate change.

Intellectual Merit: Research funded by this project showed that trees can alter their physiology in response to their growth environment to limit how much drought they experience, principally by shifting how they allocate resources to different tissues (i.e. growing leaves versus branches). The PI published multiple scientific papers demonstrating that multiple tree species show the same shifts in physiology across the landscape, that these shifts are primarily due to ‘plasticity’ or acclimation rather than to genetic differences between populations living in different places, and that these shifts in physiology have important implications for how well species will deal with ongoing climate change, where and when droughts will cause forest mortality, and how we model plants in our global vegetation models.

Broader Impacts: Through this fellowship, the PI was able to engage in professional development that ultimately helped him secure and prepare for a faculty position at the University of California Santa Barbara. He also formally and informally mentored undergraduate students and graduate students in the scientific method, work-life balance, and developing durable skills for the job market. Multiple mentees have since gained acceptance to PhD programs, while others have secured desired jobs outside of academia. The PI also engaged in numerous outreach activities, including talks to after-school high school programs, lectures to Stanford Continuing Studies students of all ages, seminars to land managers, and participation on a state-wide forestry committee.
